summary.seg: This primarily alchemical compendium was condemned by M.R. James as 'A hideous book'. Although the famous bibliographer openly confessed his ignorance of alchemical materials, his descriptions in the 1900-1905 catalogue of Western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College, which contains the richest alchemical holdings in Cambridge, only occasionally hint at his frustrations. His unpublished notes on the manuscripts in Cambridge University Library, however, are sometimes more candid. For the present, 'hideous' manuscript, he judged rather harshly that it is written in 'many hands, all rough and ugly'; instead of providing a full collation, simply described it as 'a conglomerate of quires'; and distilled his distaste into the quoted one-phrase summary. What was this alchemical compendium doing in the University Library's collection?

What James, as a scholar of his time, may not have been able to appreciate fully, is that the survival of an early modern alchemical manuscript outside of a specialist collection was in itself remarkable. It is worthwhile, therefore, placing MS Kk.6.30 into its historical context. This was one of a handful of alchemical manuscripts that entered the University Library in 1715 as part of, in James Henry Monk's words, 'the greatest benefaction which Cambridge ever yet received': the library of John Moore, the Bishop of Ely (1646-1714) (see Monk, The Life of Richard Bentley, D.D. (London, 1833), vol. I, p. 377). Moore was a voracious collector of early printed materials; indeed, Thomas Dibdin is said to have referred to Moore as 'the father of black-letter collectors in this country'. While he was Bishop of Norwich (1691-1707), Moore was able to develop and expand his library while delegating practical tasks such as paying for acquisitions to his chaplains. Among them was his son-in-law, Thomas Tanner (1674-1735), who was also a scholar and antiquary and took an instrumental role in recording Moore's collection (on which more below). Over time, Moore's library grew to be one of the most remarkable in England, with particular strengths in the areas of theology, history, and classics; and the many scholarly visitors to Ely Place in Holborn, London, where Moore housed his library following his translation to the See of Ely, enjoyed being granted access to it. At Moore's death, the library was believed to contain nearly 30,000 volumes and was, again according to Monk, 'valuable not only for its extent [...], but for the rarity of its treasures, both printed and manuscript'.

The manuscripts, while only c. 1,790 in number, reflect Moore's rather wide-ranging interests. The epitaph on Moore's monument in Ely Cathedral celebrates 'his unrivalled medical knowledge', and therefore the presence of medical manuscripts in his collection is not surprising. The much smaller number of alchemical manuscripts, among them the present manuscript (see also Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.4.45, MS Ee.1.13, and potentially MS Gg.1.8), reflects almost certainly a medically inclined individual's natural interest in historical chymical literature rather than an actual desire to make the philosophers' stone. In 1715, these manuscripts entered Cambridge University Library as part of Moore's collection, which had been purchased by King George I of Great Britain and Ireland, Elector of Hanover following Moore's death and then been donated by him to the University in its entirety. If Moore's library had been dispersed, the fate of the alchemical manuscripts might have been very different.

Focussing on MS Kk.6.30, a closer look soon reveals that the manuscript's identification as a 'book' is primarily thanks to the function of its binding. Between the boards – a later binding for Cambridge University Library retaining an older spine label reading 'ALKIMIA M.S.' – are at least seven distinct parts of different periods (in the 15th and 16th centuries), origins, and contents; written in several hands on both paper and parchment; and surviving in varying states of preservation. The volume ends with a stub that shows the potential fate all parts might have suffered if someone had not grouped them together at some point. This person was most probably Moore, as Thomas Tanner's historic manuscript catalogue (Cambridge, University Library, MS Oo.7.50(2), entry no. 898) provides nothing to suggest that the present volume was different – apart from the binding – when it was part of Moore's collection.

Tanner prosaically described the volume as 'Several tracts of Alchimy and the Philosophers Stone in Latine and old English (imperfect) some by Geo. Riplay' (in fact, a fragment of George Ripley's Compound of alchemy, ff. 41v-45v), and lists three items from the contents: the Breve breviarium of pseudo-Roger Bacon (ff. 87-103r), the Rosarium philosphorum of pseudo-Arnold of Villanova (but presented here anonymously, ff. 111r-117v), and a piece explicitly attributed to Arnold of Villanova, 'Speculativa et practica...de lapide philosophorum' (now known to be a pseudonymous attribution, and a fragment of the Speculum alchimiae, ff. 118r-127v). There are further a great number of untitled, unattributed, and anonymous alchemical recipes, texts, and fragments in the manuscript (e.g. two texts by pseudo-Albertus Magnus on ff. 1r-29a verso), which have only been identified in recent scholarship. Altogether, both the parts of the manuscript and the volume as a whole are a good representation of the alchemical texts that circulated in manuscript in Latin, and as time went on also in the vernacular, in England in the early modern period.

As someone who has followed in James's footsteps, with early 21st-century resources at my disposal and a background in the history of alchemy, I would finally like to direct the reader's eye to a feature of this manuscript that has moved from something of a scholarly blind spot into the spotlight: the functional and instructive sketches of alchemical equipment that appear in parts of the text. There is, for example, a drawing labelled 'walworte' showing 'an erbe yat groweth in ye grounde' – recognisable, with some imagination, as the roots of what is now often known as danewort (Sambucus ebulus) – amidst the text of the pseudo-Albertus Magnus Mirror of lights (at f. 11r). Overleaf (f. 11v) is an assemblage of furnaces and flasks, neatly labelled and shown in action, and the following pseudo-Albertus Magnus text from the Semita recta features drawings of alchemical apparatus on several pages, one of them filled almost entirely with illustrations (ff. 17r-17v, 19v, 26v, 28r-28v). These and the other sketches in this manuscript, all accompanied by texts written in the same, serviceable hand, will never match the more obvious beauty of elaborate illuminations, but in the eye of this beholder, they elevate this manuscript from merely instructional to instructive. Like the manicule that points from the margin to the alchemical symbols explained in the text of f. 38v, they continue to ask readers to stop, observe, and learn.

supportDesc.support: The manuscript consists almost entirely of paper leaves, except for three parchment leaves (ff. 71, 79, 86).

foliation.p: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos, by an unidentified hand of the 20th century (probably first half), completing and correcting a partial foliation sequence by earlier, 19th-century hands.

Two unfoliated conjoint parchment stubs are found between ff. 92 and 93, and another two between ff. 128 and 129 and after f. 141. These form part of the binding and have therefore not been counted either in Extent or in Foliation. For the purposes of their description here, they have been assigned the numbers ff. [92a]-[92b] and [128a] and [141a] respectively, and are described separately in Parts 6 and 7.
An unfoliated paper stub is found between ff. 117 and 118. Other than a single word on the verso, 'domine', it is blank and has not been photographed.
Folio 133a is a blank but foliated paper stub between f. 132 and f. 133b.

foliation.note: Numbering in brown ink in the lower right-hand corner of the rectos.

collation.formula: Part 1: collation not established | [1]12+2-4 (one leaf added before 1st and one after 12th; 8th, 10th, and 12th excised) | [2]16 | [3]12 [4]12-1 (one leaf excised in 2nd half of quire) | Part 5: collation not established | [5]14-1 (5th excised)

binding.p: Quarter leather binding with brown leather on the spine and grey paper sides; a flat spine with blind-tooled quarters and red leather strip gold-tooled frame and gold-stamped inscription: ALKIMIA.

provenance.p: John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 898 in the handwritten supplementary list of Moore's manuscripts, now CUL Oo.7.50(2), compiled by Thomas Tanner (1674-1735) Tanner, Thomas, 1674-1735 after the publication of Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on the inside of the upper cover.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on Margaret Connolly Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo), The Index of Middle English Prose, 17 (Cambridge: Brewer, 2009); Anke Timmermann, 'Alchemy in Cambridge: An Annotated Catalogue of Alchemical Texts and Illustrations in Cambridge Repositories', Nuncius: Journal of the Material and Visual History of Science, 30:2 (2015); and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. JamesJames, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.6.30, ff. 1r-61v

msItem.title: Mirror of lights [incomplete]
msItem.author: Pseudo-Albertus Magnus
msItem.incipit: 1r In sekyng ouȝte of þe sothenes of this crafte þat men callen alkemye .3. maner of condicions þer muste be knowne
msItem.explicit: 15v Anon it schall be tornede jn to water or els meng it togeder vpon
msItem.note: The text is imperfect at the end.

msItem.title: Semita recta [English translation]
msItem.author: Pseudo-Albertus Magnus
msItem.rubric: 16r Here begynnethe a gude chapiter namyde dyabesse the whyche ys clepede rebus
msItem.incipit: 16r Moriene seythe to florydum kepe þou þat j schall schewe the yfe þe werke be of fyr the behovethe to knowe þe quantyte of þe furnes and how it schall be made
msItem.explicit: 29a verso and solde full der þey beth precyous a tyncture there is callede mercury þat transumythe all

msItem.title: Unidentified alchemical treatise (including recipes)
msItem.incipit: 29b recto hit be drye and þen [...] bodye of glas and þen sette it in a furnes with [...]
msItem.explicit: 33v and quenchede þer in it schall be both whyeght and maleable in all maner of assayes etcaetera
msItem.note: The treatise refers to John Styward on f. 30v: Opus Johannis Stywarde.

msItem.title: Alchemical recipes
msItem.note: The recipes refer to John Frynge (Conclusio sepius probata per magistrum johannem frynge et vera utipse confessus fuit pro certe) and the rector of Wymington, Bedfordhisre (Opus rectoris de Wymentoun Canonici) on f. 33v.

msItem.title: Turba Philosophorum (excerpts)
msItem.incipit: 35r Capitulo primo The sotell þat is firste mater of all metalles
msItem.explicit: 36r and moste perfyte dominacion of þe laste redenes þat is þe ende of þe phelosophers warke

msItem.title: Turba Philosophorum (excerpts)
msItem.incipit: 36r Pictagoras seyth take þe combust
msItem.explicit: 37v and anoþer seyth passe noȝte a pece of golde

msItem.title: Tract on the operations of alchemy
msItem.incipit: 37v There ben 7 termes of keys whiche be rotes of oryginall creacion of þe blessede tre beyng grene uppon þe hyll of natoir
msItem.explicit: 38v in all thynges be þes ordered above seyd be naturally knytke knytte withowt handy werkeyng with hete. moyste. Colde and. drye. etcetera Amen
msItem.note: As Connolly (2009), p. 294 notes, the tract is elsewhere entitled: Septem claues huius scientie.

msItem.title: List of names for planets and metals (Alphabetum alcanamik)
msItem.incipit: 38v Golde syluer mars
msItem.explicit: 38v atoun Rede calamyn

msItem.title: On making furnaces
msItem.incipit: 39r Some ffornes muste be more and some lesse after þe quantyte of þe wercke
msItem.explicit: 39v and þe furnes muste be covered wiþ a thycke and stronke couercle made of goode erth with a hole in þe tope etcaetera
msItem.note: The tract is preceded by a drawing of four furnaces, which are identified as: The furnes of calcinacion and sublimacion, Furnes of sublimacion, The furnes of dystylling, and The furnes of reuerberacion.
As Connolly (2009), p. 295 notes, this tract may be derived from a longer text that survives in Cambridge, University Library, Ee.1.13, ff. 150r-150v.

msItem.title: Alchemical recipe
msItem.incipit: 39v Take wat vessell þou wylte of earth to glase and anoynt it with paste
msItem.explicit: 39v Rugeplum made of Ceruse and of tyne is a 1000 folde parte better þen Rugeplum made of leede

msItem.title: Instruction for multiplying the stone
msItem.incipit: 39v When þou wulte multeply þe rede stone se howe muche þe stone wheythe and put þerto þe 4th parte of his weythe of mercurij well clensede
msItem.explicit: 40r and multeply þe [fourth] parte with Mercurij as afor seyd etcaetera

msItem.title: Untitled alchemical treatise on the stone and elixer
msItem.incipit: 40r Ther is a naturall well þat is noyntede made of þe mounte of vulcane
msItem.explicit: 41v after liber turbe þe phelesopheres ston owt to be mad of our es and water lastyng and of nonoþer thynges etcaetera

msItem.title: The Compound of Alchemy or Twelve Gates, Prose version [imperfect]
msItem.author: George Ripley
msItem.incipit: 41v Jn the begynnyng when þou mad all thyng of noȝghte / a globous matere and derke vnderconfucion
msItem.explicit: 45v lyeke as jn blackenes moystour doth hym shewe / Be colours varyante ay newe and Newer

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: A recipe on f. 47r ends: secundum Rosarum.

msItem.title: Table of months and days
msItem.note: The table has 12 rows with the names of the months in English written alongside them, and 31 numbered columns, containing no entries.

msItem.title: Nativity of John Corfe (1483)
msItem.incipit: 49r figura nativitatis John Corfe 1483 perfecto 26 die Julij hora 8 minuta 41 post meridie[m] / die saturday
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Nativity of Elizabeth Lauwe (1483)
msItem.incipit: 49r figura nativitatis Elizabeth Lauwe 1483 perfecto 13 die december hora [8] minuta 30 post meridie[m] / die Saturni
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Nativity of John Robronte
msItem.incipit: 49r figura nativitatis John Robronte de Meratyng Anni Christi 1486 \perfecto/ þe 16 da[e] [of] \march/ hora [0] minuta 10 \post meridiem/ diei [...]
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Nativity of John May (1502)
msItem.incipit: 49r Nativite John May þe sonne of John May þe ȝer of Christ 1502 þe 4th day of Septembre horas 12. Minutas .15. etcaetera
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Nativity of John May (1504)
msItem.incipit: 49r Nativite John May þe ȝer Christi 1504. þe .10. day March þe 2a hora .15. minuta. dominus diei. N. dominus hora late paste
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Nativity of William Munde (1506)
msItem.incipit: 49r Nativite William filijs de William Munde Anno CHristi 1506 die descembre .5. hora 14 minuta .30. diei N inperfectum
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Note on two motets
msItem.incipit: 49v mon amye q Leo / Sont deux motez qui fomit entre plussierue lotez
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.incipit: 49v O Jhesu esto mi Jhesus / Jhesus mercie notre dame aydez - Aydez notre Dame
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Saying
msItem.incipit: 49v [?] Viuit et incedit paries si fronte carebit
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Poem on motets
msItem.incipit: 49v Si deu motets nous ne fuissent
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Memorandum about quantities and types of cloth
msItem.incipit: 49v Memorandum þat 5 colen elles maketh 4 elles ff and so 500 elles colen maketh 400 elles fflemysche stud 40 boges skynys maketh a kepe item 40 golde skynnes makethe a kepe item bruges mader ys þe [crossed out: bestmader] best mader item 6 a colen threde maketh a doss etcaetera
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Speculum Alkymy, extract of English translation [A Compendyos Abstract of Alkamy]
msItem.author: Roger Bacon
msItem.rubric: 50r Her begynneth a compendyos abstract of alkamy drawyn out of latyn by /a\ trew grounde on what whys ȝe schall whyche without Error to trewe conclucion of aparfit Elixir bothe for whyȝt and þe rede
msItem.incipit: 50r To all þat [word deleted] vertuosly ar disposide wyllyng to be þe chyldern of doctryn
msItem.explicit: 58r for þat be tokens temperans of fyere and goodnes of praparacion

msItem.title: Medical recipe to make a tooth fall out
Recipe for making gilt
msItem.incipit: 58v þus is made water of sulphurfyse for to gylde with take 2 libri of sulphurfyse and i libri sal vitri and medell þem well togedre
msItem.explicit: 58v ande yȝf þou anoynte þer wiþ a peny of a plate of coper yt schall turnyn to colour of fyn gold

msItem.title: De lapide
msItem.author: Raymond Llull
msItem.incipit: 58v It is opyne and pleyne that the operacion of oure medysyne is the operacion of nature
msItem.explicit: 59v but when þey have mad proieccion þey fonde non profete ffor þey mayde an ende wher þey shulde have be gone

msItem.title: Notes on alchemical 'spirit' and alchemical water
msItem.incipit: 59v ffor soth þe body jncorporates þe speryte, þe spryte tornys þe body jnto speryte
msItem.explicit: 59v wiþout hys body wiþ þe whyche he is laysede and þey be made one, he may not be permanent

msItem.title: Alchemical recipes
msItem.textLang: Middle English recipes with Latin headings

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in folio. featuring various watermarks, including a : a hand with a six-pointed star, jug, and bull's head.

collation.p: Collation not established. It is possible that this part consists of several separate codicological units (e.g. ff. 50r-59v) but it has not been possible to securely identify such further parts.

signatures.p: Leaf signatures consisting of a combination of the letter "C" and Arabic numerals (1-6) written in the first half of the quire (ff. 6-10 only).

catchwords.seg: A catchword in brown ink in the right lower corners of the last versos on f. 5v.

p.seg: Folios 1r-45v and 60r-61r ruled in hardpoint, frame only (only vertical lines visible). Single columns. 26-28 lines to the page.
Folios 46r-47v ruled in ink, frame only. Single columns. 26-27 lines to the page, written below top line.
Folios 50r-59v ruled in hardpoint, frame only (only vertical line in the outer margin visible). Single columns. 29 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Folios 1r-45v and 60r-60v perhaps copied by a single hand in a script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Folios 46v-47v (lower half) copied by a single hand in a script with mostly secretary features.
Folios 47v (upper half)-48v copied by a single hand in a script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Folios 49r-49v copied by various hands in cursive scripts with both anglicana and secretary features.
Folios 50r-59v copied by 2 or 3 (?) hands in a script with with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: Alchemical drawings in brown ink, showing: alchemical furnaces and vessels on f. 11v; furnaces on ff. 17r, 17v, 19v, and 39r; alchemical vessels on ff. 26v, 28r [with a heart], 31r, and 34r; and vessels with a distillation setup on f. 28v; and a list of alchemical symbols on f. 38v.
Drawing of the herb danewort (Waltworte) in brown ink on f. 11r.
A drawing of a wheel with holes in brown ink inserted in (and illustrating) the text on f. 16r.
Large (2- or 3-line) initials in brown ink with minor forms of decoration (ff. 1r, 16r, 25r, 33v, 41v, 43v).
Manicules drawn in margins in brown ink (e.g. ff. 5v, 14v, 15v, 17r, 22r, 37v, 38v, 39v, 40r, 41v, 42r, 44v, 45v).

origin.origDate: Second half of the 15th century or first quarter of the 16th century.
origin.p: A clue for the manuscript's origin may be a Maltese cross with at each of its four ends the number '4' or letter 'q' written in brown ink in the upper margin of f. 1r.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.6.30, ff. 62r-70v

msItem.title: De consideratione quintae essentiae [excerpts]
msItem.author: John of Rupescissa
msItem.incipit: 62r Scientia ad extrahendum [quintam] essenciam de Antimonio id est marcasita Plumbea / Deus celi ipse stestis est quod nuncupatur ego stantum Secretum stibi reuelabo
msItem.explicit: 62v Et Scias quod Istud oleum habet dulcedinem maximam

msItem.title: Liber Lucis
msItem.author: Pseudo-John of Rupescissa
msItem.incipit: 62v In nomine domini Amen Ego frater Iohannes de Rupescissa consideram tribulatione
msItem.explicit: 68v pro Infinita Seculorum Secula Amen
msItem.finalRubric: 68v Explicit liber quj vocatur Magisterium lucis

msItem.title: Poem on woman's faithlessness
msItem.incipit: 70v I se ryght well ther is but lytill trust / On to this world ay so full of bruttylte
msItem.explicit: 70v Thus ham I rokyd hydyr and theder / The deuyll sett fyer on all to geder
msItem.note: Added by a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in folio. Folios 62r-70v: rumble bell (?)

list.item: Quire [1]12+2-4 (ff. 61-70: a bifolium has been added to the sexternion, one before the 1st leaf and 1 after the 12th; 8th, 10th, 12th have also been excised)

collation.note: The quire number has been placed in square brackets to indicate that the number does not represent its actual position in this manuscript, but its order in the quires that can be collated.

p.seg: Ruled in hardpoint, frame and line. Single columns. 27-28 lines to the page, written above top line.

handNote.p: Folios 62r-68v have been written by a single hand in a cursive script that can be described as Gothica Cursiva Libraria.
The text on folios 70v has been added by a single hand in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: Large (1- to 2-line) initials in red ink.
Small (1-line) regular initials higlighted in red ink.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.6.30, ff. 71r-86v

msItem.title: Codicillus
msItem.author: Pseudo-Ramon Llull
msItem.incipit: 71r perficitur rote prime elimentorum conuersionis ad et in nostro declaramus testamento De modo perficiendi rotam imperfectam
msItem.explicit: 86v nisi inquantum virtus sua valet a[ccidentiam etcaetera]
msItem.note: This is a previously unidentified copy of Pseudo-Lull's Codiccilus. The text in this manuscripts corresponds with Chapters XXXI ('De Inhumatione et vivificatione corporis per (V)') until Chapter L, subsection De sublimacione Mercurij et nutrimento per multiplicacionem.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in folio with four parchment leaves (ff. 71, 78, 79, 86). Folios 72-77 and 80-85: bull.

collation.note: The quire number has been placed in square brackets to indicate that the number does not represent its actual position in this manuscript, but its order in the quires that can be collated.

signatures.p: Quire signatures consisting of combinations of letters (a) and Roman numerals (i-viij) written in dark ink in the lower right corners of the first half of the quire.

catchwords.seg: A catchword written in the lower right corner of f. 86v.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. 33-35 lines to the page, written above top line.

handNote.p: Copied by a single hand in a Gothica Cursiva Libraria with both Uncial 'd' and Humanistic 'd'.

decoNote.p: Two large (5- to 6-line) Champ-style gold initial against a ground of blue and purple and with spraywork in the same colours extending into the margins (ff. 74r, 80v).
Large (2- to 4-line) initials in blue ink with penwork decoration inside the letter and pen-flourishing in red ink.
Small (1-line) initials alternatively red and blue ink.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.6.30, ff. 87r-109v

msItem.title: Breve breviarum
msItem.author: Pseudo-Roger Bacon
msItem.incipit: 87r Breve breuiarium abbreuiatum sufficit intelligenti si fuerit diligens ignoranta autem
msItem.explicit: 103r Custodi igitur ipsum etceatera et redde deo gracias
msItem.finalRubric: 103r Explicit extractum breuis breuariarum. M. R. B.

msItem.title: Liber experimentorum
msItem.author: Pseudo-Roger Bacon
msItem.incipit: 104v Incipit secretum secretorum [...] de compositione medicine auree que lunam preparatam certissime conuertit in solem
msItem.explicit: 106r omnes iste vie operacionum licet secundum diuersum effectum vere sunt et experte et caetera

msItem.title: Tractatus de vegetabilibus et sensibilibus
msItem.author: Pseudo-Roger Bacon
msItem.incipit: 106r Inter vegetabilia autem frumentum virtutis maioris obtinet principatum
msItem.explicit: 108r si non adde ad hanc de oleo et iterum solue et coagulam ut ipse nosti

msItem.title: Price list of chemical ingredients
msItem.note: The list begins with Azorum [coe] - vs and ends with Sal armoniak - xxd.

extent.note: Folios [92a] and [92b] are parchment stubs between ff. 92 and 93. Both originate from the same manuscript and show fragments of the same Latin text. (See Part 7 for further details).

list.item: Quire [4]12-1 (ff. 99r-109v: 1 leaf missing in the second half of the quire)

collation.note: The quire numbers have been placed in square brackets to indicate that the number does not represent its actual position in this manuscript, but its order in the quires that can be collated.

p.seg: Ruled in hardpoint, frame only. Single columns. 30 lines to the page, written above top line.

handNote.p: Copied by a single hand in a script with both anglicana and cursiva features.

decoNote.p: One large initial in a frame of penwork decoration and with pen-flourishing in brown ink (f. 87r)

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.6.30, ff. 110r-128v

msItem.title: De cognitione lapidis philosophici
msItem.author: Pseudo-John Dastin
msItem.incipit: 110r [C]vm gaudeant vti breuitate moderni verborum abreuiatum verissimum
msItem.explicit: 110r cognosce possibilia Inspice vegitabilia

msItem.title: List of ingredients for an alchemical process
msItem.incipit: 110r Sal armoniac ij li. [...] - bulliantur in aceto
msItem.explicit: 110r Sal armoniac [...] - Crudum

msItem.title: Rosarium philosophorum
msItem.author: Pseudo-Arnold of Villanova
msItem.incipit: 111r Hic incipit quidam liber abreuiatus valde certus et probatus thesaurus thesaurorum. Rosarius philosophorum et omnium secretorum
msItem.explicit: 117v quia omnia naturaliter sunt vera que nullus philosofus meliora Dixit
msItem.finalRubric: 117v Explicit speculatiua Deo gracias / [crossed out: Magistri Johannis de melvuum] et Eiusdem Arndoldy de villa noua [crossed out: Incipit Practica]

msItem.title: Speculum alchimiae (fragment)
msItem.author: Pseudo-Arnold of Villanova
msItem.rubric: 118r Incipit practica magistri Arnoldi de villa noua de lapide philosophorum
msItem.incipit: 127v Manifestum est quod lapis noster resoluitur in argentum vivum per magisterium artificium
msItem.explicit: 127v et esse socius sapientum antiquorum. deo gracias
msItem.finalRubric: 127v Explicit practica magistri Arnolde de villa nova de lapide philosophici et est m[agisterium] solemne

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in folio. Folios 110r-128v: Fleur-de-lis and Mountain

catchwords.seg: Catchwords written on the right lower margins of versos do not necessarily coincide with the end of quires; one catchword written on the outer lower margin of f. 120r and f. 127r.

p.seg: Ruled in hardpoint, frame only. Single columns. 32-39 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Folios 111r-117v and 118r-127v have been copied by one or possibly two scribes in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Folios 110r-110v and 127v-128v contain recipes by different hands (possibly including the hand(s) seen on 111r-117v and 118r-127v) in cursive scripts with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoDesc.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant form of decoration.

origin.origDate: Second half of the 15th century or first quarter of the 16th century.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.6.30, ff. 129r-141v

msItem.title: Testamentum (opening line)
msItem.author: Pseudo-Ramon Llull
msItem.incipit: 129r Sic incipit anima metallorum / O eterna sapiencia Summa et perdurabilis prudencia

msItem.title: Music notation with the opening words of a love song
msItem.incipit: 129r ffree lusti fresch most goodly
msItem.note: The text is written below one staves with music notation.

msItem.title: Astronomical notes
msItem.incipit: 129r Memorandum elong. lune ad horam 3am post merediem anno 17o die junij
msItem.explicit: 129r In quorum conclusi reperietur [...] motum - 56

msItem.title: Secretum secretorum
msItem.author: Pseudo-Pliny
msItem.incipit: 129v Hic incipit tractatus optimus in quo exponit et aperte declarat Plinius philosophus qui sit lapis philosophicus eo ex qua materia debet fieri
msItem.explicit: 131r quod qui ipsam habent incomparabilem habent thesaurum Recipe 7 haec sufficiat quantum ad praesens

msItem.title: Rosarium Philosophorum (fragment)
msItem.author: Pseudo-Arnold of Villanova
msItem.incipit: 131r De igne multipici ad operandum in alkis sic intelligendum est. Est autem ignis multiplex et qualitas eius diuersa per quosdam gradus distincta
msItem.explicit: 131v et est iudex iustus discernens et separans iustum ab iniusto bonum a malo purum ab impuro et mundum ab inmundo

msItem.title: Alchemical poem
msItem.incipit: 131v In speciem solis lunam convertere si vis
msItem.explicit: 131v Ad pondus maste latonem pulueris adde
msItem.note: Another copy of this poem, entitled Conversio lunae in solem, is extant in Geneva, Bibliotheque de Geneve, Ms. lat. 82, f. 131r.

msItem.title: List of ingredients
msItem.incipit: 131v Catelettecum imperiale
msItem.explicit: 131v Binitides vnatae

msItem.title: Tract on firing (fragment)
msItem.incipit: 133b recto and sett it in þe said furnes in soft fire as a hennys egge oþer ij dais
msItem.explicit: 133b recto and make fire above and be neþe ij dais etcaetera
msItem.note: The text has been crossed out.

msItem.title: Alchemical recipes
msItem.note: The recipes refer to a certain 'Richard' (Secundum Ricardus) on f. 133b recto.

msItem.title: Alchemical recipes
msItem.note: Two recipes on f. 136r are attributed to 'Robert Bolton' (Secundum R. Bolton).

msItem.title: Alchemical recipes and notes
msItem.note: The recipes refer to a 'M. K. G. G.' (Secundum M[agistrum] K. G. G.) on f. 137v.

msItem.title: Alchemical recipes
msItem.note: The recipes refer to 'Hulman' on f. 138r. One recipe on ff. 140r-140v ends with the explicit: Explicit capitulum lucie.

msItem.title: Line on a Canterbury monk
msItem.incipit: 138v Dan John ledis moncke of Canterbure / and wiliam gold duellyng by þe abbey gate of þe same toun

msItem.title: Astronomical note
msItem.incipit: 139r tres menses id est tres dies naturales

msItem.title: Poem on (?) Simon de Langham, Archbishop of Canterbury
msItem.incipit: 141v [exultent] celi quia Symon transit ab Ely / Symonu[m] adventum flent in Kent milia centium
msItem.note: Full transcription. The poem may concern the translation of Simon de Langham, Bishop of Ely, to Canterbury, when he was elected Archbishop in 1366.

msItem.title: Poem on (?) John Salmon, Bishop of Norwich
msItem.incipit: 141v Ex Ely veniens si[...]s in honore locatur / Nec rex nec sapiens Salamon tamen ipse vocatur
msItem.note: Full transcription. This poem occurs with minor variations as part of the 14th-century macaronic poem 'Flen, Flyys, and Freris' (Fleas, flies, and friars).

msItem.title: Location with reference to Dagenham
msItem.incipit: 141v iiij myle beȝonde dagnam in Essexe
msItem.note: Full transcription. The text is continued on the stub of f. [141a] verso.

msItem.title: Account of a petition, dated 1381/2
msItem.incipit: 141v Buk. xva et xa In primis petit exonerari de xxxs
msItem.explicit: 141v Anno quinto Richardi Secundi inde editis [?] iregularis memorandum de termino pasche eodem Anno ex parte
msItem.note: The text refers to lands held by John Osbaldeston (name partially written on f. [141a] verso).

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in folio. Folios 129r-141v: bull and circle (?)

extent.note: Folio [128a] is a parchment stub before f. 128 and f. [141a] is a parchment stub after f. 141; both originate from the same manuscript and show fragments of the same unidentified 15th-century Latin text (f. [128a] verso and f. [141a] recto). (See Part 7 for further details).

p.seg: Ruled in hardpoint, frame only. Single columns. 36-42 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Folios 129v-131r have been copied in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Folios 131r-131v have been copied in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant form of decoration.

origin.origDate: Second half of the 15th century or 1st quarter of the 16th century.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.6.30, ff. [92a]-[92b]

msItem.title: (?) Privilegium concessum rectori et fratribus hospitalis pauperum beatae Mariae Senesnis ab Alexandro IV. Summo Pontifice, Anno 1257
msItem.author: Pope Alexander IV
msItem.incipit: [92a] verso exequantur illi tamen studeant laudabilius adimplere qui hospitalitati
msItem.explicit: [92b] recto propter que dominus in ultimo districtionis

extent.seg: 1 fragmentary leaf, comprising a folded strip of parchment recycled from another manuscript and reused as a sewing guard. These stubs have not been photographed.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.6.30, ff. [128a] and [141a]

extent.seg: 1 fragmentary leaf, comprising a folded strip of paper recycled from another manuscript and reused as a sewing guard. Only the second of these stubs has been photographed.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.6.30, ff. [128a] and [141a]

extent.seg: 1 fragmentary leaf, comprising a folded strip of paper recycled from another manuscript and reused as a sewing guard. Only the second of these stubs has been photographed.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
